metadata.case_name: Appellants (Private Bus Operators) v. State of U.P.

facts.text: The appellants along with many others have been carrying on the business of plying motor vehicles as stage carriages on hire on the Bulandshahr-Delhi route for a number of years past.

The running of these vehicles has been regulated by the Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 which provides for granting of driving licences, registration of vehicles and control over transport vehicles through permits granted by Regional Transport Authorities.

Section 42(3) of the Motor Vehicles Act exempts transport vehicles owned by or on behalf of the Central or Provincial Government from the necessity of obtaining permits unless used in connection with the business of an Indian State Railway.

Some time after 1947, the Government of U.P. conceived the idea of running their own buses on public thoroughfares, first as competitors with private operators but later decided to exclude all private bus owners and establish complete State monopoly.
Transport Authorities began cancelling permits already issued to private operators and refusing permits to others entitled to them, using provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act.
Private bus owners filed petitions under Article 226 in Allahabad High Court against illegal use of Motor Vehicles Act by U.P. Government.

Full Bench of five Judges in Allahabad High Court held that State could not discriminate under s.42(3) in its own favour, sub-section conflicts with Article 14; nationalisation not possible by executive order without legislation justifiable under Article 19(6). Directed Transport Authorities to deal with permit applications without influence of State policy.
U.P. Road Transport Act (Act II of 1951) passed and became law on 10th February 1951 to provide for State Road Transport Services.
Notification dated 25th March 1953 under s.3 of the Act declared that stage carriage services on Bulandshahr-Delhi route inter alia shall be run exclusively by State Government.
Notification dated 7th April 1953 set out scheme for operation of State carriage services on these routes.

Two appellants and 106 other private bus owners filed writ petitions under Article 226 before Allahabad High Court praying for mandamus directing U.P. Government and Transport Authorities not to interfere with their operations and to refrain from operating except per Motor Vehicles Act.
Division Bench of Allahabad High Court (Mukherji and Chaturvedi JJ.) dismissed writ petitions by judgments dated 17th November 1953.
Appeals to Supreme Court on certificates granted by High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951 violates Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution and cannot be justified as reasonable restriction under Article 19(6).
Whether the Act deprives appellants of property/interest in commercial undertaking without compensation, violating Article 31(2).
Whether the Act is discriminatory violating Article 14.
Whether the Act violates freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse under Article 301.

petitioner_arguments.text: Right to carry on occupation, trade or business guaranteed by Article 19(1)(g); Act prevents plying buses, conflicting with this right.
Beneficial interest in commercial undertaking is property under Article 31(2); Act does not conform to requirements.
Right to use public highway for trade is easement/property; deprived by Act.
Act discriminatory under Article 14: discriminates in favour of State against private individuals; unfettered discretion to associate persons.
Violates Article 301 freedom of inter-State and intra-State trade.

respondent_arguments.text: No fundamental right to carry trade anywhere; must have legal right to use particular place; bus owners have no inherent right to ply on public road beyond passing/repassing; rights created by State legislation and can be taken away.
Creation of State monopoly justifiable as reasonable restriction under Article 19(6) in interests of general public for efficient transport.
No acquisition of petitioners' right; State always had equal right to run buses; mere prohibition not attracting Article 31(2).
Classification inherent in monopoly; State differentiated rationally.

court_reasoning.text: Public has right of passage over highway extending to vehicular traffic including motor vehicles as incident of public right, anterior to Motor Vehicles Act; using for trade/business attracts Article 19(1)(g).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to ply motor vehicles on public road exists as incident of highway right; State regulates but does not create it.

court_reasoning.text: 'Restriction' in Article 19(6) normally implies continued existence, not total prohibition; even if includes prohibition, no materials show reasonableness or public interest benefit; immediate effect deprives hundreds of livelihood without compensation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No materials on conditions of bus service or improvements from monopoly; violates Article 19(1)(g) not saved by Article 19(6) as stood then.

court_reasoning.text: Deprivation of interest in commercial undertaking (right to ply buses) is deprivation of property under Article 31(2); no compensation provided.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Articles 31(1) and (2) read together; intangible business interest protected.

court_reasoning.text: Classification for State monopoly rational; no unfettered discretion as permits regulated by Motor Vehicles Act.
No final decision on Article 301 as unnecessary; indicated arguments possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article 301 may protect individual rights; restrictions need Presidential sanction.

holdings.text: U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951 violates Article 19(1)(g) and not saved by Article 19(6); void under Article 13(2).
Act deprives property without compensation, violating Article 31(2).

precedents_cited.relevance: American doctrine of extraordinary use not applicable in India.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.S.S. Motor Service v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Public roads vest in State as trustee; right to carry business on public roads under Article 19(1)(g).
Restriction implies continued existence of right.
Reasonableness depends on nature of trade; not absolute prohibition.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.
Commonwealth of Australia v. Bank of New South Wales
precedents_cited.relevance: Monopoly judged on facts; Article 301/92 protects individuals.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Corporation of Toronto v. Virgo

precedents_cited.relevance: American view of extraordinary use rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Exempts govt vehicles from permits; used discriminatorily; regulates permits.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Declares State monopoly; schemes; exclusive rights; offences; held unconstitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; trade right and restrictions; property; trade freedom; basis for challenge.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; judgment of High Court set aside; writ of mandamus issued restraining respondents from enforcing U.P. State Road Transport Act, 1951 against appellants.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus restraining enforcement of the Act.

key_quotes.text: The true position then is, that all public streets and roads vest in the State, but that the State holds them as trustees on behalf of the public.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines State's role over highways; citizens' right to use for business.

key_quotes.text: Within the limits imposed by State regulations any member of the public can ply motor vehicles on a public road. To that extent he can also carry on the business of transporting passengers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies Article 19(1)(g) to road transport business.

key_quotes.text: The legislation in question which violates the fundamental right of the appellants under article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution and is not shown to be protected by clause (6) of the article, must be held to be void under article 13(2).
key_quotes.speaker: court
